p.s: In his newspaper article John Worne claims that language learning is vital for the UK's prosperity and global standing

On the one hand one could argue that nowadays, specifically for the UK, the importance for international communication could have gone down a bit since Brexit happened, however on the other hand I believe the article has written prior to Brexit happening and this also might mean that the UK must focus on learning languages of other countries more than ever, especially since learning the EU might have opened opportunities to trade with new countries and at the same time forces them to focus on not loosinglosing their connections with EU countries any further and to rely on working with China.

Even though English is globally spoken, as also referred to by Worne, (cf. ll. 18-23) I believe that it is still important for British children to learn multiple languages, since Spanish and chineseChinese are also becoming more and more of a competition to being the global language.

Also I personally feel there is a huge benefit in leaving other countries' culture and history instead of just focussing on oneself, since it enables people to travel and really live in way adventurers a hundred years ago could only have dreamt of.

Even though I agree with the critics saying phones will play a more important role and help break language barriers, I feel like relying on phones too much will make people of the future dull and less capable of thinking by them selvesthemselves, they will be completely reliant on their device.
Additionally studies have shown that learning a new language is very beneficial to train the brain and thus enhance learning capability overall.

Moreover, as already written by Worne, more and more jobs require language skills that reach further than merely English (cf. ll 28-30) and more jobs than ever require their employees to travel around the world.
Also due to globalization more and more hotels have opened, causing more business partners to be international, in all sectors.

Furthermore there is manymuch/ a lot of outsourcing going on (also cf. ll34-35), which means only people who can move with the tide and build up a life elsewhere can keep up with the role in which everything changes in our world.
Last but not least I personally feel there is something levseley arrogant and nationalistic in refusing to learn anything but the "own" culture and language, simply because so many people speak it.
This gives one a bad taste of a superiority-complexsuperiority complex and seems, to me, to lead to a way less diplomatic future.
In conlusionconclusion I would very much say I agree with John Worne and feel like the UK's future is not looking totoo bright if they don't start learning more foreign languages at a young age.
The market has rapidly expanded and the world is at our feet to be explored.
If the UK doesn't keep up with it'sits international connections forged by trade, diplomacy and student exchanges, they will quickly fall behind their competitors.
